Fig. 2 Influence of hydrogen pressure: (a) conversion versus time and (b) the initial rate (10min) versus hydrogen pressure. Conditions: 0.2g 5% Pd/C (Degussa), 4mmol/L HMR in 2-propanol, 90°C, HMR2/HMR1 initial ratio=1.9. Fig. 3 Conformers of (7R,8R,8′R)-(−)-7-allo-hydroxymatairesinol (HMR 1) adsorbed on the palladium surface, similar conformers are found for the other isomer. The denotations for the conformers are found from Taskinen et al. [21] and the numbers in parentheses are the energies (in kcal/mol). Fig. 4 The HMR molecule adsorbed on palladium surface. Depending on the adsorption structure, HMR covers ∼10–20 Pd surface atoms. Fig. 5 Plot of ln(c HMR1/c 0,HMR1) versus ln(c HMR2/c 0,HMR2). Fig. 6 Estimated curves compared with experimental points: (a) 4bar, (b) 8bar, (c) 13bar, (d) 18bar, (e) 28bar, and (f) 34bar. Table 1 Results from parameter estimation. Parameter Estimated value Estimated relative standard error (%) k ″ 1 4900Lg−1 min−1 3.9 k 3 0.00059Lg−1 min−1 72.9 k 4 0.00060Lg−1 min−1 64.5 k ′ 5 120Lg−1 min−1 19.9 K MAT 2.55×106 Lmol−1 2.0 K H 0.0221bar−1 2.0 Describing the inverse dependence of hydrogen pressure by multi-site adsorption of the reactant: Hydrogenolysis of hydroxymatairesinol on a Pd/C catalyst Heidi Bernas 1 Antti Taskinen Johan Wärnå Dmitry Yu. Murzin ⁎ Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry and Reaction Engineering, Process Chemistry Centre, Åbo Akademi University, Biskopsgatan 8, FI-20500 Åbo/Turku, Finland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +358 2 215 4985; fax: +358 2 215 4479. 1 nee Markus. The hydrogenolysis of the lignan hydroxymatairesinol (HMR), extracted from Norway spruce knots, to matairesinol (MAT) was done in a stainless steel autoclave using a 5% Pd/C. The influence of hydrogen pressure (4–40bar) was studied and the hydrogenolysis reaction rate was proved to decrease at higher hydrogen pressure. This was explained by competitive adsorption of HMR and hydrogen, where HMR adsorbs on several Pd atoms. The kinetic results were described with a model applying multi-site adsorption for the reactant, where the number of Pd surface atoms needed for the adsorption of a single HMR molecule was determined to 20 using molecular modelling. The values of the rate and adsorption constants were estimated using a parameter estimation program. The kinetic model explained the experimental data well. Graphical abstract The hydrogenolysis of the lignan hydroxymatairesinol (HMR), extracted from Norway spruce knots, to matairesinol (MAT) was done in a stainless steel autoclave using a 5% Pd/C. The influence of hydrogen pressure (4–40bar) was studied and the hydrogenolysis reaction rate was proved to decrease at higher hydrogen pressure. This was explained by competitive adsorption of HMR and hydrogen, where HMR requires several sites for adsorption. Keywords Hydrogen pressure Multi-site adsorption Kinetics 1 Introduction Until now, close to 500 different lignan structures have been identified from plants [1]. Lignans, which form a group of plant phenols consisting of two β-β-linked cinnamic acid residues [2], are found in the wooden parts, roots, leaves, flowers, fruits and seeds. During the last decades, the interest in lignans has increased after studies have shown that lignans have anticarcinogenic [3] and antioxidative [4] effects. Detailed information about lignans in trees can be found from the article by Holmbom et al. [5], who also discovered large amounts of the lignan hydroxymatairesinol (HMR) in Norway spruce (Picea abies) knots [6], i.e. the part of the branch that is embedded in the tree. Knots are harmful in pulp and paper manufacturing and should be removed before pulping [5]. However, since valuable lignans are present in these knots, the waste material from pulping industry can be used for synthesis of pharmaceuticals and technical antioxidants. Because no other lignan has been found in substantial amounts in nature, other lignans that are of great interest and importance should be synthesized starting from HMR. The lignan matairesinol (MAT) is of interest, since MAT was concluded to be superior to HMR in studies performed in vivo; the quantity of the mammalian lignan enterolactone, which reduces the cancer risk, was over twofold when MAT was used as precursor compared to when HMR was used [7]. High radical and superoxide scavenging activities were also observed for MAT [8]. We have studied the hydrogenolysis of HMR to MAT. In our previous studies, we have investigated the influence of support acidity for carbon supported [9], zeolite supported [10] and carbon nanofibre (CNF) supported [11] palladium catalysts. Moreover, we have studied deactivation and solvent effects [12]. Not only the catalyst and solvent affect this reaction, but also reaction parameters such as catalyst particle size, stirring rate, catalyst mass, reaction temperature and reactant concentration, as concluded in our most recent publication [13]. Furthermore, we have earlier done a preliminary study on the influence of hydrogen pressure [14] and noticed that reaction rate is inversely dependent on the hydrogen pressure. In this work, the hydrogen pressure was varied from 4 to 40bar and the results were fitted to a model that recognizes the difference in size of the bulky organic molecule and hydrogen. 2 Experimental 2.1 Hydrogenolysis of hydroxymatairesinol The isolation of hydroxymatairesinol from Norway spruce knots is described in detail in Ref. [9]. There are two diastereomers of hydroxymatairesinol, (7R,8R,8′R)-(−)-7-allo-hydroxymatairesinol (HMR 1) and (7S,8R,8′R)-(−)-7-hydroxymatairesinol (HMR 2), the ratio between HMR 1 and HMR 2 can vary from tree to tree. The simplified reaction scheme is presented in Fig. 1 . The main reaction is hydrogenolysis of HMR to the desired product matairesinol (MAT), which can react further to by-products. HMR and the solvent 2-propanol can also react to 7-iso-propoxymatairesinol (7-i-propoxyMAT, two diastereomers). The experiments were done in an autoclave (300mL, Parr Co.), which was equipped with a heating jacket, a cooling coil and a sampling line (0.5μm metal sinter). A hollow shaft concave blade impeller was used to ensure efficient mixing (stirring rate 1700rpm). A 5% Pd/C catalyst supplied by Degussa (E196 NN/W, water wet, dried in oven over night at 100°C) was utilized. The catalyst (0.2g) was reduced in situ at 100°C for 1h in hydrogen flow before the experiments. The reactor was equipped with a bubbling unit allowing the reactant solution to be injected to the bubbling unit and degassed before it was lead into the reactor. The reaction temperature was 90°C, the initial concentration of HMR was 4mmol/L in 135mL 2-propanol (Fluka, 99.8%) and the HMR2/HMR1 initial ratio was 1.9. Samples were taken at different time intervals and analysed by a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a HP-1 column (length 25m, inner diameter 0.20mm, film thickness 0.11μm) and a flame ionisation detector (FID) operating at 300°C. The samples were silylated prior to analysis using N,O-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoro-acetamide. The silylation procedure and the analysis are described in Ref. [11]. 2.2 Molecular modelling Adsorption of HMR on the Pd(111) surface was modeled by molecular mechanics [15] (MM) with the COMPASS (condensed-phase optimized molecular potentials for atomistic simulation studies) force field [16] as implemented in the Forcite molecular mechanics module in Materials Studio 4.1 (Accelrys Software Inc.). The COMPASS force field has been used before, for example, to model gas diffusion and sorption on the surface of metal oxides [17]. As the force fields cannot properly model chemisorption and, consequently, exact structures of the adsorbed molecules, the role of the metal surface in the MM calculations was mainly to act as a steric constraint, similarly as in recent studies [18,19]. The flat Pd(111) surface was represented by a three-layer thick slab of dimensions 3nm×3nm×0.5nm. During the calculations, all Pd–Pd distances were kept fixed to the experimental value of 275.1nm of bulk Pd. The atomic charges of HMR were determined using the QEq charge equilibration method [20] as implemented in Materials Studio. The charges of all Pd atoms were set to zero. Adsorption of all the main conformers (dd, de, du, ed, ee, eu, ud, ue, and uu) of the (7R,8R,8′R) isomer of HMR was studied on the metal surface (for the nomenclature, see Taskinen et al. [21]). The gas-phase optimized structures of the conformers, taken from reference [21], were placed near the surface and re-optimized. As each conformer has several faces that can approach and interact with the surface, several adsorption structures are feasible. In this study, structures where the reacting CHOH moiety of HMR lies close to the surface were considered. 2.3 Kinetic modelling Non-linear regression analysis was performed using the simulation and parameter estimation software ModEst [22]. The system of ordinary differential equations was solved with the backward difference method implemented in the software Odessa. The sum of residual squares, Q, was minimized with the hybrid simplex–Levenberg–Marquardt method: (1) Q = | | c exp − c est | | 2 = ∑ t ∑ i ( c exp , i t − c est , i t ) 2 where c exp denotes experimental data and c est the estimated values. An indication of the reliability of the model is the degree of explanation, R 2: (2) R 2 = 100 1 − | | c exp − c est | | 2 | | c exp − c ¯ exp | | 2 where c ¯ exp is the mean value of the experimental data. The accuracy of the model predictions was determined using Markov chain Monte Carlo methods (MCMC) [23]. MCMC methods are Bayesian statistical methods that can be used for analyzing the distribution of parameters in nonlinear models in order to extend and support the information given by traditional regression analysis [23]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of hydrogen pressure The effect of hydrogen pressure on the hydrogenolysis of HMR was investigated and Fig. 2a shows conversion versus time when the hydrogen pressure is varied. At higher hydrogen pressure, the reaction was substantially retarded. From Fig. 2b, which illustrates the initial rate (moles converted per second and gram metal) as a function of hydrogen pressure in the interval 4–40bar, it is visible that lower hydrogen pressure is preferred and after 18bar the reaction rate is decreasing dramatically. The selectivity to the desired product MAT was, up to 80% conversion (the selectivity decreased with conversion), over 90% for all pressures applied. Meitzner et al. [24] studied the influence of hydrogen pressure (0.1–10atm) on the reaction rate of methylamine hydrogenolysis and observed that the rate increased with pressure until an optimum, after which the reaction rate decreased as the hydrogen pressure increased. They suggested that the rate-limiting step at lower pressures was a step where hydrogen is involved, and at higher pressures the rate-limiting step would be another one. We have suggested a reaction mechanism in Ref. [9] for the hydrogenolysis of HMR. The first step is protonation (H+ coming from the support) of the hydroxyl group. This is followed by the breakage of the carbon–oxygen bond and water abstraction. The carbenium ion is attacked by a hydride ion (hydrogen adsorbed on the catalyst) and MAT is formed. We have earlier studied the influence of acid site concentration on the hydrogenolysis of HMR [9–11]. It was observed that the reaction rate increased as a function of acid site concentration when Pd/C [9] and Pd/CNF catalysts [11] were used, but for palladium catalysts supported by H-Beta zeolite the reaction rate decreased as a function acid site concentration [10]. The concentration of Brønsted acid sites is higher for H-Beta than for activated carbon and CNF, which means that for low concentration of Brønsted acid sites the reaction rate increases with increasing acidity, and for high concentration of Brønsted acid sites the reaction rate decreases with increasing acidity. Brønsted acid sites, palladium and hydrogen are all necessary for the hydrogenolysis of HMR to take place [10]. We suggest that at low concentration of acid sites, the rate-limiting step is the protonation of the hydroxyl group. At low hydrogen pressure, the addition of a hydride to the HMR carbenium ion intermediate could be the rate-limiting step, for a catalyst that is not deficient in acid sites. At higher pressure, the hydrogen can hinder adsorption of the reactant HMR. The decrease in reaction rate at high hydrogen pressure is explained by competitive adsorption of hydrogen and reactant; at higher hydrogen pressure less Pd surface atoms are available for HMR to adsorb on, which results in lower reaction rate. To explain negative reaction order in hydrogen at higher hydrogen pressures, the difference in size between the large reactant and the small hydrogen atom should be taken into account. This approach has been used originally by Frennet et al. [25–27], later on by Siffert et al. [28] and more recently by Cabrera and Grau [29,30]. Frennet et al. studied the adsorption of saturated hydrocarbons and estimated the number of sites to be seven [25] and eight or more [26], whereas Siffert et al. [28] carried out 2-methylpentane skeletal transformation and obtained a good description of the experimental results with a model with eight sites for adsorption. Methyl oleate hydrogenation and isomerization were studied by Cabrera and Grau, who found that the cis- and trans-methyl oleate could cover up to 11 sites [30]. In our work, the number of Pd surface atoms needed for the adsorption of a single HMR molecule was elucidated and utilized in kinetic modelling. 3.2 Adsorption of hydroxymatairesinol on Pd(111) surface Figures of the optimized adsorption structures (top views) and their molecular mechanics energies (in the parentheses, in kcal/mol) are presented in Fig. 3 . The stability of the structures decreases as the energy increases. Fig. 4 illustrates how the HMR covers several palladium atoms with the number varying between 10 and 20 depending on the conformer. The most stable structures cover more metal atoms than the least stable ones. Since the molecule most probably occurs as the most stable conformer, it is assumed that the number of Pd surface atoms needed for the adsorption of a single HMR molecule is 20. This was also supported by preliminary parameter estimation resulting in a value of 20±1.5 Pd surface atoms. 3.3 Kinetic modelling The experimental data was described using a model, where hydrogen and HMR competitively adsorb on the catalyst surface and the difference in size of reacting molecules is taken into account. Hydrogen dissociates and adsorbs on the palladium surface according to Eq. (3): (3) H 2 + 2 * ≡ K H 2 H * For hydrogen adsorption equilibrium we get: (4) K H = θ H 2 p H θ * 2 The two diastereomers of HMR, namely HMR 1 and HMR 2, adsorb on z Pd surface atoms (in our case z is equal to 20): (5) HMR 1 + z * ≡ K HMR1 HMR 1 z * (6) HMR 2 + z * ≡ K HMR 2 HMR 2 z * HMR is then protonated by a proton originating from the support, resulting in intermediates I1 (from HMR 1) and I2 (from HMR 2). (7) HMR 1 z * + H + ≡ K I 1 I 1 z * (8) HMR 2 z * + H + ≡ K I 2 I 2 z * Since steps (7) and (8) are in equilibrium and the concentration of protons is regarded as constant, the concentrations for I1 and I2 can be written as (9) [ I 1 ] = K I 1 [ H + ] [ HMR 1 z * ] (10) [ I 2 ] = K I 2 [ H + ] [ HMR 2 z * ] The intermediates react with dissociatively adsorbed hydrogen to MAT: (11) I 1 z * + H * → k 1 MAT z * + * (12) I 2 z * + H * → k 2 MAT z * + * HMR also reacts to 7-i-propoxyMAT (two diastereomers), but this reaction does not require palladium [11]: (13) HMR 1 + 2 -propanol → k 3 7 -i-propoxyMAT 1 + H 2 O (14) HMR 2 + 2 -propanol → k 4 7 -i-propoxyMAT 2 + H 2 O MAT either desorbs from the surface or reacts to byproducts BP: (15) MAT z * + H * → k 5 BP + ( z + 1 ) * The coverage is obtained from the following balance equation: (16) θ * + ( K HMR 1 ( 1 + K I 1 c H + ) c HMR 1 + K HMR 2 ( 1 + K I 2 c H + ) c HMR 2 + K MAT c MAT ) θ * z + K H p H θ * = 1 The following rate equations were used in the parameter estimation: (17) r 1 = k 1 θ I 1 θ H = k 1 K I 1 c H + K HMR 1 c HMR 1 θ * z + 1 K H p H (18) r 2 = k 2 θ I 2 θ H = k 2 K I 2 c H + K HMR 2 c HMR 2 θ * z + 1 K H p H (19) r 3 = k 3 c HMR 1 (20) r 4 = k 4 c HMR 2 (21) r 5 = k 5 θ MAT θ H = k 5 K MAT c MAT θ * z + 1 K H p H We can lump k 1 K I 1 c H + to k ′ 1 and k 2 K I 2 c H + to k ′ 2 , since c H + is regarded as constant. The rate equations are combined with the following mass balances for all components in the batch reactor: (22) d c HMR 1 d t = r HMR 1 = ( − r 1 − r 3 ) m cat V (23) d c HMR 2 d t = r HMR 2 = ( − r 2 − r 4 ) m cat V (24) d c MAT d t = r MAT = ( r 1 + r 2 − r 5 ) m cat V (25) d c propoxy 1 d t = r propoxy 1 = r 3 m cat V (26) d c propoxy 2 d t = r propoxy 2 = r 4 m cat V (27) d c BP d t = r BP = r 5 m cat V where m cat is the catalyst mass and V is the liquid volume. The system is clearly over-parameterized and therefore the amount of parameters has to be diminished. The number of parameters has already been decreased when fixing the value for z (the number of Pd surface atoms covered by one HMR molecule) to 20. If z is not fixed but instead estimated, several possible solutions exist and such a model is not reliable. Another possibility to exclude some of the parameters is to find a relationship between some parameters and then to remove one of them. If Eq. (22) is divided by Eq. (23), assuming that r 3 and r 4 are negligible compared to r 1 and r 2 since the amount of formed 7-i-propoxyMAT is very low, one arrives at (28) r HMR 1 r HMR 2 = − r 1 − r 2 = k ′ 1 c HMR 1 k ′ 2 c HMR 2 (29) d c HMR 1 d c HMR 2 = k ′ c HMR 1 c HMR 2 (30) ∫ c 0 , HMR 1 c HMR 1 d c HMR 1 c HMR 1 = k ′ ∫ c 0 , HMR 2 c HMR 2 d c HMR 2 c HMR 2 (31) ln c HMR 1 − ln c 0 , HMR 1 = k ′ ( ln c HMR 2 − ln c 0 , HMR 2 ) (32) ln c HMR 1 c 0 , HMR 1 = k ′ ln c HMR 2 c 0 , HMR 2 Fig. 5 presents a plot of ln(c HMR1/c 0,HMR1) versus ln(c HMR2/c 0,HMR2) for different hydrogen pressures. The slope gives k′ equal to 0.5, which means that k ′ 2 is twofold the value of k ′ 1 and thus this ratio was used in the calculations. The rate equations combined with the mass balances were used in the parameter estimation according to the procedure described in Section 2.3. An initial estimation showed that adsorption constants for HMR 1, HMR 2 and MAT correlate with each other and that the values for K HMR1 and K HMR2 were much lower than 1 while the value for K MAT was around 106. Since the coverage of MAT was much higher than the coverage of HMR, the coverage of HMR can be neglected. This could be explained by HMR reacting rapidly to MAT, once it has adsorbed on the surface. Still, HMR needs 20 Pd surface atoms (sites) to adsorb, therefore 20 vacant sites in the rate expressions for HMR 1 and HMR 2 should be included, but the coverage of HMR can be omitted from Eq. (16). Thus, Eqs. (5)–(12) could be rewritten in the following form: (33) HMR 1 + H + + z * + H * → k ′ 1 MAT z * + * (34) HMR 2 + H + + z * + H * → 2 k ′ 1 MAT z * + * We then arrive at the following equations: (35) θ * + K MAT c MAT θ * z + K H p H θ * = 1 (36) r 1 = k ′ 1 c H + c HMR 1 θ * z + 1 K H p H = k ″ 1 c HMR 1 θ * z + 1 K H p H (37) r 2 = 2 k ′ 1 c H + c HMR 2 θ * z + 1 K H p H = 2 k ″ 1 c HMR 2 θ * z + 1 K H p H (38) r 3 = k 3 c HMR 1 (39) r 4 = k 4 c HMR 2 (40) r 5 = k 5 K MAT c MAT θ * z + 1 K H p H = k ′ 5 c MAT θ * z + 1 K H p H The results from the parameter estimation are seen from Table 1 . The relative standard errors are larger for k 3 and k 4 (73 and 65%, respectively) than for the rest of the parameters, but this is due to the small parameter values. The degree of explanation was 97.3%. The estimated curves compared with the experimental points are presented in Fig. 6 . The model fits the experimental results at both low and high pressure, while at the medium pressures some underestimation is seen. The sensitivity analysis showed that the model describes the results well and that no significant correlation between the parameters exists at the optimum; the absolute values of the correlation coefficients were less than 0.6 for all cases except for k ″ 1 and K H which was 0.8. 4 Conclusions The hydrogenolysis of hydroxymatairesinol (HMR) to matairesinol (MAT) was performed in a pressurized autoclave using a 5% Pd/C catalyst. The influence of hydrogen pressure in the range from 4 to 40bar was studied. The hydrogenolysis rate was clearly retarded at higher hydrogen pressure. This was explained by competitive adsorption of reactant and hydrogen, and multi-site adsorption of reactant. Hydrogen adsorbs dissociatively on the catalyst surface and at higher hydrogen pressure the HMR adsorption was hindered. The number of Pd surface atoms needed for the adsorption of one HMR molecule was determined to 20 by using molecular modelling. The values of the rate and adsorption constants were estimated using a parameter estimation program. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenolysis of the lignan hydroxymatairesinol (HMR), extracted from Norway spruce knots, to matairesinol (MAT) was done in a stainless steel autoclave using a 5% Pd/C. The influence of hydrogen pressure (4–40bar) was studied and the hydrogenolysis reaction rate was proved to decrease at higher hydrogen pressure. This was explained by competitive adsorption of HMR and hydrogen, where HMR adsorbs on several Pd atoms. The kinetic results were described with a model applying multi-site adsorption for the reactant, where the number of Pd surface atoms needed for the adsorption of a single HMR molecule was determined to 20 using molecular modelling. The values of the rate and adsorption constants were estimated using a parameter estimation program. The kinetic model explained the experimental data well.
coredata.dc:title: Describing the inverse dependence of hydrogen pressure by multi-site adsorption of the reactant: Hydrogenolysis of hydroxymatairesinol on a Pd/C catalyst
